review.title: Deterministic POMDPs Revisited
review.abstract: We study a subclass of POMDPs, called Deterministic POMDPs, that is characterized by deterministic actions and observations. These models do not provide the same generality of POMDPs yet they capture a number of interesting and challenging problems, and permit more efficient algorithms. Indeed, some of the recent work in planning is built around such assumptions mainly by the quest of amenable models more expressive than the classical deterministic models. We provide results about the fundamental properties of Deterministic POMDPs, their relation with AND/OR search problems and algorithms, and their computational complexity.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Fifth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2009)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Fifth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2009)

metadata.title: Deterministic POMDPs Revisited

sections.text: We are investigating a subclass of POMDPs, called deterministic POMDPs, characterized by deterministic actions and observations. These models do not offer the same universality as POMDPs, but they capture a number of interesting and challenging problems and enable more efficient algorithms. In fact, some of the recent planning work is mainly based on such assumptions in the search for accessible models that are more meaningful than the classic deterministic models. We are providing results on the fundamental properties of deterministic POMDPs, their relationship to AND / OR search problems and algorithms and their computational complexity.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The simplest models for sequential decision-making are the models with the known beginnings and objectives. Solutions are the sequences of actions that return the original state to a state that can be calculated using standard search algorithms. Indeed, this model has been studied with important contributions such as A *, IDA * and others. The deterministic model has strong limitations on the type of problems that can be presented. It is not possible to explore situations where the states are not fully observable.

sections.heading: 2 Examples
sections.text: For reasons of space, we provide only a few examples and brief descriptions of some of them. Mastermind. There is a secret word of length above an alphabet of n symbols. The goal is to discover the word by making guesses about it. At each guess, the number of exact matches and near-matches is returned. The goal is to obtain a strategy for identifying the secret. Navigation in partially known terrains. There is a robot in an n × n grid that must navigate from a starting position to a target position. Each cell of the grid is either feasible or not feasible. The robot has perfect scanning within its cell, but the traversability of a subset of cells is unknown. The task is to obtain a strategy for guiding the robot to its target position [20]. There are binary tests to find out the state of a system among possible states.

sections.heading: 3 Model and Variants
sections.text: In fact, it is an unforeseen situation, in which the result of the application to the State i, a deterministic observation function o, a deterministic transitional function f (i, a).S, for i).S, indicates the result of the application to the State i, (i, a).O, for the State i, which receives the observation, after the application of the State i, and the positive costs c (i, a).S, for the State i, which takes the measures.

sections.heading: 3.1 Optimality Criteria
sections.text: We consider two optimality criteria and three variants of the model. For optimality, we consider the Minmax, which minimizes the worst costs of a policy, and the Minexp, which minimizes the expected costs of a policy. Variants of the model depend on the observation model: • non-observable models, in which O is a singleton and thus does not provide information about the state. This class is a subclass of the so-called conformity problems in planning [13]. • fully observable models, in which o (i, a) = i. This class corresponds to fully observable mdps, except that the initial state is unknown, but after the application of the first measure the state is revealed. • Models without assumptions about the observations. This case corresponds to general detpomdps and includes the previous cases. Two optimization criteria and three variants combine to form six models: non-observable models with the minimum and general exminable models, which are not observable criteria and non-observable states.

sections.text: Let us think about the trajectories generated by a policy that cannot be predicted with certainty. In the beginning, the agent applies the action a0 = π (b0). Then, the agent accepts certain direct costs depending on the current state and action used by the agent to update his original belief in b1 = (b0) o0a0. It is important to point out that during the execution of a policy the agent cannot predict with certainty.

sections.heading: 4 AND/OR Graphs
sections.text: We establish a relationship between guidelines and AND / OR graphs that can be exploited by algorithms. An AND / OR graph is a tuple G = (V1, V2, E, T, n0, c), where V1 and V2 are finite sets of AND and OR nodes, E '(V1, V 2)\ T · (V1, V2) is a subset of directed edges between nodes, T'V2 is a subset of end nodes, n0, V1, V2 is the root node, and c: E, T, R is a cost function over edges and end nodes [26]. sections.heading: 5 Complexity
sections.text: The complexity of the politics of finite costs has been thoroughly investigated. Results for various optimization criteria, probable and non-deterministic variants, and so on are known [17, 22, 25, 28, 33]. [21] Actually obtained important complexity results on detpomdps for problems with non-negative costs (i.e. with non-positive rewards): • Decision on the existence of a policy that results in zero costs for an endless view of things: • Deciding on the existence of a policy of polynomial length that is in zero costs for a det-pomdp is NP-completeIn this section, we expand these results as follows: Deciding on the existence of a policy of finite costs for det-pomdps of polynomial diameter is NPcomplete, • there are dets-pomdps on which all strategies of finite costs of finite size are • we enter a new class of problems on which the existence of the politics of finite costs can be verified.

sections.heading: 5.1 Permutation Groups and Their Diameter
sections.text: It is generally known that a permutation in cycle notation can be written as the product of disjunctural cycles, and that the order σ = C1C2. Cm (in cycle notation) is the least common multiple for the lengths of the cycle. For example, the order in which a permutation in cycle notation can be written as the product of disjunctural cycles, and that the order σ = (1, 3, 5, 8) (2, 4, 7) (6) and its order is ord (duration) = lcm {4, 3}. Let us now consider a non-observable model with a single action corresponding to an empty precondition corresponding to a permutation = C1C2 · Cm over states. Furthermore, let us assume that b0 m has states from each cycle Ci.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: We have shown that the deterministic POMDP model, first examined by Littman, is more relevant than previously thought for two reasons: firstly, a number of important and challenging problems in planning correspond to such models, and secondly, because they represent a trade-off between the restricted but efficient classical deterministic model and the general but inefficient Pomp model. We have shown novel complexity results that demonstrate this trade-off: While verification of the existence of plans in classical deterministic (flat) problems is NL-complete (via st-Reachability [35]), and verification of the existence of plans for Pomp models is EXPTIME-complete [21], we have found that verification of the existence of plans for Pomp plans with polynomial diameter NP is complete, and that for Pomp models in which actions are mutations with empty preconditions are allowed in NP.

metadata.abstractText: We study a subclass of POMDPs, called Deterministic POMDPs, that is characterized by deterministic actions and observations. These models do not provide the same generality of POMDPs yet they capture a number of interesting and challenging problems, and permit more efficient algorithms. Indeed, some of the recent work in planning is built around such assumptions mainly by the quest of amenable models more expressive than the classical deterministic models. We provide results about the fundamental properties of Deterministic POMDPs, their relation with AND/OR search problems and algorithms, and their computational complexity.
